snippet.title: Young Sikhs in Maryland fight bias with diplomacy in the classroom
snippet.description: Members of a Sikh community in Maryland combat misunderstanding with education.

snippet.title: Arizona tribe set to prosecute first non-Indian under a new law
snippet.description: The Justice Department and all of Indian country are watching the Pascua Yaquis closely.

snippet.title: 57-nation OSCE plays key Ukraine monitoring role
snippet.description: A 57-nation organization with a history of mediation but no enforcing powers has been tasked with helping to translate diplomatic progress on easing Ukrainian tensions into reality on the ground.

snippet.title: Can the Republican Party thrive on white identity?
snippet.description: With increasing ethnic diversity, identity politics will cut both ways.

snippet.title: Hot hoods: Logan Circle/Shaw
snippet.description: Once riddled with strip clubs, massage parlors and auto malls, Logan Circle (and neighboring Shaw) have undergone quite a revival to become two of the trendiest hoods in town.

snippet.title: Killing of environmental activists rises globally
snippet.description: As head of his village, Prajob Naowa-opas battled to save his community in central Thailand from the illegal dumping of toxic waste by filing petitions and leading villagers to block trucks carrying the stuff â€” until a gunman in broad daylight fired four shots into him.

snippet.title: Is Barack Obama 'black'? A majority of Americans say no.
snippet.description: A majority of Americans don't describe him that way in Pew polling.

snippet.title: Don't forget Taiwan in a Trans-Pacific Partnership expansion
California city turns up heat on Sriracha maker
snippet.description: A small Southern California town has turned up the heat on the makers of the wildly popular Sriracha hot sauce, telling them that if they can't keep their bottling plant from smelling up the neighborhood, the city will.

snippet.title: 2 nations leading jet search have turbulent past
snippet.description: The leaders of Malaysia and Australia have used warm and glowing terms to assure the world that their partnership in the desperate hunt for a missing airliner is built on a firm and abiding friendship. But it's also an odd-couple relationship that has proved brittle in the past and has been blighted by hostility, rivalries and cultural misunderstandings.
